bestBHT.bht: Jesus went into the region of Galilee, but not to that part called 'His own country,' Nazareth. He acted on the maxim that a prophet hath no honour in his own country. This maxim explains Jesus's motive in going into Galilee, where he had not yet labored and where he apparently had no such fame as in Judea and now in Samaria. Jesus understood that he would not be properly received by those who were familiar with him, therefore he sought new areas to share his message.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He went into the region of Galilee, but not, as might have been expected, to that part of it called 'His own country,' Nazareth.
He acted on the maxim which He oft repeated, that 'a prophet,' &c.
Albert Barnes: Jesus went to Galilee, but not to Nazareth, for he testified," etc.
Jesus went to Galilee, 'although' he had said that a prophet had no honor in his own country...
...yet, because he foreknew that the Galileans would many of them believe on him, he went at this time.
Marvin Vincent: For - in His own country [γαρ - εν τη ιδια πατριδι] . For assigns the reason why Jesus went into Galilee. By His own country, Judaea seems to
Archibald T. Robertson: A prophet hath no honour in his own country."
Does John refer to Judea by 'his own country'? If so, the application hardly fits for he had already explained that Jesus was leaving Judea because he was too popular there."

But even so this is probably John's meaning for he is speaking of the motive of Jesus in going into Galilee where he had not yet laboured and where he apparently had no such fame as in Judea and now in Samaria.
John Gill: For Jesus himself testified, that a prophet hath no honour in his own country."
These words must not be understood as a reason why Christ left Judea, and went into Galilee, because he had no honour in Judea, in which was Bethlehem, the place of his nativity.
They treated him with great disrespect and contempt.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus went into the region of Galilee, not to his own country of Nazareth, because he knew that a prophet hath no honour in his own country. He acted on this maxim, recognizing that his own country, whether it be Judea or Galilee, would not properly receive him. Although some may argue that this quote does not appear to apply to Judea since Jesus was leaving Judea due to his popularity there, it is likely that John is referring to Judea as Jesus's own country. Regardless of the specific location, the verse emphasizes the lack of honor Jesus received from those who were familiar with him, as they treated him with contempt and disrespect.

Jesus went into Galilee, not to His own country of Nazareth, for He testified that a prophet hath no honour in his own country. Despite his previous popularity in Judea, it is likely that John is referring to Judea as Jesus's own country. Regardless, the verse highlights the lack of respect and honor Jesus received from those familiar with Him, which ultimately led him to seek out new areas where His message could be received with fresh ears.

Jesus went into the region of Galilee, but not to that part called 'His own country,' Nazareth. He acted on the maxim that a prophet hath no honour in his own country. This maxim explains Jesus's motive in going into Galilee, where he had not yet labored and where he apparently had no such fame as in Judea and now in Samaria. Jesus understood that he would not be properly received by those who were familiar with him, therefore he sought new areas to share his message.
